  In situ three-dimensional spider web construction and mechanics

        Abstract
        
      

      
        
          
            
              
                


  
    
      
      Spiders are nature's engineers that build lightweight and high-performance web architectures often several times their size and with very few supports; however, little is known about web mechanics and geometries throughout construction, especially for three-dimensional (3D) spider webs. In this work, we investigate the structure and mechanics for a Tidarren sisyphoides spider web at varying stages of construction. This is accomplished by imaging, modeling, and simulations throughout the web-building process to capture changes in the natural web geometry and the mechanical properties. We show that the foundation of the web geometry, strength, and functionality is created during the first 2 d of construction, after which the spider reinforces the existing network with limited expansion of the structure within the frame. A better understanding of the biological and mechanical performance of the 3D spider web under construction could inspire sustainable robust and resilient fiber networks, complex materials, structures, scaffolding, and self-assembly strategies for hierarchical structures and inspire additive manufacturing methods such as 3D printing as well as inspire artistic and architectural and engineering applications.
    

  

  


              
            

          
        
      

      
    

    

    
      


  

  
    
      
        
          Keywords:
        
      
      art-science; construction; mechanics; silk; spider webs.
    

  


    

  



  
  


  
  PubMed Disclaimer

          Figures
        


        
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 1. 

    
  

  
     3D spider web-scanning setup. (... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 1. 

    
  

  
     3D spider web-scanning setup. (  A  ) Schematic of the scanning setup. (... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 1.
    
  

  
    3D spider web-scanning setup. (A) Schematic of the scanning setup. (B) Image of the scanning setup. The frame and the spider are placed on top of a water-filled container so that the spider is only allowed move within it and hence builds the web within the frame. The camera takes high-resolution images of slices illuminated by the sliding sheet laser. (C) T. sisyphoides spider (female).

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 2. 

    
  

  
     Comparison between scans and model... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 2. 

    
  

  
     Comparison between scans and model of the 3D spider web under construction. (... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 2.
    
  

  
    Comparison between scans and model of the 3D spider web under construction. (Top) Each scan image is an image superposition of all the scans over depth. (Bottom) 2D view of the 3D web model. The web density increases as the construction progresses.

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 3. 

    
  

  
     Fiber length and node degree... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 3. 

    
  

  
     Fiber length and node degree distribution histograms over 7 d of web construction.... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 3.
    
  

  
    Fiber length and node degree distribution histograms over 7 d of web construction. (A) The fiber lengths follow a skewed distribution (bars in blue), as most fibers are shorter than 4 mm. As the construction progresses, the fiber length median increases within the first 2 d, then is stable after the third day of construction. The increase in the fiber length distribution between each day and its previous day (bars in green) shows that most of the long fibers (length > 10 mm) were constructed during the first 2 d, and after that short fibers (length < 10 mm) were mostly used to reinforce the network. (B) The node degree is the number of fibers that are connected together at a node. Nodes of degree 1 and 2 are fiber extremities that are attached to frame boundary. Most nodes are of degree 3, which is consistent with what has been derived for the C. citricola spider web (12).

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 4. 

    
  

  
     Web strength and toughness increase... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 4. 

    
  

  
     Web strength and toughness increase with density, which increase over building time. (... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 4.
    
  

  
    Web strength and toughness increase with density, which increase over building time. (A) Stress–strain curves of 3D spider webs at different construction stages under uniaxial stretching along the x- (red), y- (green), and z-axes (blue). (B) Variation of strength and toughness with web sample density. Web strength and toughness increase with density, which increases as web construction progresses.

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 5. 

    
  

  
     Projectile impact deceleration map. The... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 5. 

    
  

  
     Projectile impact deceleration map. The color map represents the ratio of the speed... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 5.
    
  

  
    Projectile impact deceleration map. The color map represents the ratio of the speed after web impact over speed at impact (0.5 m/s) (units in centimeters). Most prey projectiles fly through the web because of its high porosity. After the first day of construction, the web can decelerate prey projectiles at very specific locations and consequently increase its capture.

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 6. 

    
  

  
     Physical models of the scanned... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 6. 

    
  

  
     Physical models of the scanned webs.  A  shows a small section of the... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 6.
    
  

  
    Physical models of the scanned webs. A shows a small section of the web on day 7, printed for close visual inspection at large scale. B depicts the entire web on day 1. The left shows the 3D model and the right the printed specimen, in both cases, for direct visual comparison.

  


                
              

            
          
            
              
                
              

              
              

              
                
                  
                  
                    


  
    
       Fig. 7. 

    
  

  
     Arduino UNO implementation for synchronizing... 


  


                  

                


                
                  
                  


  
    
       Fig. 7. 

    
  

  
     Arduino UNO implementation for synchronizing the laser scanning setup. (  A  ) Schematic... 


  


                


                
                  
                  


  
    
      Fig. 7.
    
  

  
    Arduino UNO implementation for synchronizing the laser scanning setup. (A) Schematic of the web-scanning system used here. Arduino UNO is used to synchronize movement of the laser, illumination of the web, and camera. Using this upgraded method, the scanning timing is more precise, fully automatic, and can be monitored remotely. (B) Scanning sequence of the web scanning synchronized and controlled by Arduino UNO.

  


                
              

            
          
        


        
          
            
              All figures (7)

. 2021 Aug 17;118(33):e2101296118.
doi: 10.1073/pnas.2101296118.

In situ three-dimensional spider web construction and mechanics

Isabelle Su 1 , Neosha Narayanan 1 , Marcos A Logrono 1 , Kai Guo 1 , Ally Bisshop 2 , Roland Mühlethaler 2 , Tomás Saraceno 2 , Markus J Buehler 3
Affiliations

Affiliations

  • 1 Laboratory for Atomistic and Molecular Mechanics, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139.
  • 2 Studio Tomás Saraceno, 10317 Berlin, Germany.
  • 3 Laboratory for Atomistic and Molecular Mechanics, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139; mbuehler@mit.edu.
  • PMID: 34373329
  • PMCID: PMC8379916
  • DOI: 10.1073/pnas.2101296118
Free PMC article
Item in Clipboard

In situ three-dimensional spider web construction and mechanics

Isabelle Su et al. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2021.
Free PMC article
Display options
Format
Actions
  • Search in PubMed
  • Search in NLM Catalog
  • Add to Search
. 2021 Aug 17;118(33):e2101296118.
doi: 10.1073/pnas.2101296118.

Authors

Isabelle Su 1 , Neosha Narayanan 1 , Marcos A Logrono 1 , Kai Guo 1 , Ally Bisshop 2 , Roland Mühlethaler 2 , Tomás Saraceno 2 , Markus J Buehler 3

Affiliations

  • 1 Laboratory for Atomistic and Molecular Mechanics, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139.
  • 2 Studio Tomás Saraceno, 10317 Berlin, Germany.
  • 3 Laboratory for Atomistic and Molecular Mechanics, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139; mbuehler@mit.edu.
  • PMID: 34373329
  • PMCID: PMC8379916
  • DOI: 10.1073/pnas.2101296118
Item in Clipboard
Display options
Format

Abstract

Spiders are nature's engineers that build lightweight and high-performance web architectures often several times their size and with very few supports; however, little is known about web mechanics and geometries throughout construction, especially for three-dimensional (3D) spider webs. In this work, we investigate the structure and mechanics for a Tidarren sisyphoides spider web at varying stages of construction. This is accomplished by imaging, modeling, and simulations throughout the web-building process to capture changes in the natural web geometry and the mechanical properties. We show that the foundation of the web geometry, strength, and functionality is created during the first 2 d of construction, after which the spider reinforces the existing network with limited expansion of the structure within the frame. A better understanding of the biological and mechanical performance of the 3D spider web under construction could inspire sustainable robust and resilient fiber networks, complex materials, structures, scaffolding, and self-assembly strategies for hierarchical structures and inspire additive manufacturing methods such as 3D printing as well as inspire artistic and architectural and engineering applications.

Keywords: art-science; construction; mechanics; silk; spider webs.

PubMed Disclaimer

Conflict of interest statement

The authors declare no competing interest.
